E69/1641 and E69/1642, Musgrave Project, Western Australia for the year ended 31 January 2005.  
 Since acquiring E69/1640, E69/1641 and E69/1642, Discovery Nickel Limited (DNL) has been able 
 to reach a land access agreement with the Ngaanyatjarra Council late 2005, ground work should 
 commence in mid 2006. 
 Initial investigations will focus on EM anomalies defied in GEOTEM surveys flown during 2003.

text:
(Giles  Meteorological  Station)  in  Western  Australia.    Discovery  Nickel  acquired  the  Project’s 
 tenements following the recognition of the Mesoproterozoic Giles Complex as having significant 
 potential to host nickel-copper-PGE mineralisation. The Project covers Giles Complex intrusions 
 located within the Musgrave Block, on the Bentley and Scott 1:250 000 map sheets in central 
 east Western Australia (Fig. 1).

16.text: Exploration work is aimed at discovering nickel-copper massive sulphide systems, analogous to

17.text: the giant Voisey’s Bay nickel-copper deposit in Canada.

40.text: The  area  lies  on  the  eastern  margin  of  the  Gibson  Desert  and  is  characterised  by  isolated

41.text: plateaux and sand ridges separated by ephemeral creeks, rising to more elevated terrain along

42.text: the east-west axis of the Musgrave Block.  Local elevations rise from approximately 500 metres

43.text: above  sea  level  on  the  plain  to  650  metres  on  the  hilltops.    The  vegetation  is  dominated  by

44.text: broad expanses of Spinifex and annual grassland, interspersed with isolated shrubs and trees,

45.text: consistent with a continental desert climatic regime.

Exploration work is aimed at discovering nickel-copper massive sulphide systems, analogous to 
 the giant Voisey’s Bay nickel-copper deposit in Canada. 
 Discovery  Nickel  acquired  tenements  E69/1640,  E69/1641  and  E69/1642  from  Falconbridge 
 (Aust.)  Pty  Ltd,  as  part  of  the  purchase  by  Discovery  Nickel  Limited  of  all  of  Falconbridge’s 
 Musgrave Project tenements.  Discovery Nickel acquired Falconbridge’s Musgrave tenements 
 upon  the  successful  listing  of  Discovery  Nickel  on  the  Australian  Stock  Exchange  on  17th 
 Following  the  announcement  of  the  discovery  of  the  Nebo  and  Babel  deposits  in  the  West 
 Musgraves in May 2000, Falconbridge (Australia) Pty Ltd (FL) commissioned a study to identify 
 Ni  exploration  targets  in  the  Murray  Range  area.  As  a  result,  four  exploration  licences 
 Falconbridge’s Musgrave Project. Compilation studies involving regional geology, geochemistry, 
 in  2001  comprising 
 (E69/1640,  E69/1641,  E69/1642  and  E69/1700)  were  obtained 
 airborne magnetics, regional gravity and Landsat imagery were completed.  The results of these 
 studies were reported in the first annual report.   In December 2002 and early January 2003, 
 Falconbridge commissioned Fugro Airborne Surveys to undertake a 25Hz GEOTEM survey on 
 the  three  tenements.  The  results  of  this  survey  work  were  reported  by  Falconbrdige  in  the 
 Second Combined Annual Report. 
 General access to the project area is gained via the unsealed Outback Highway from Laverton 
 to  Warburton,  thence  via  the  Warburton-Docker  River  Road  and  distributary  tracks  within  the 
 The  area  lies  on  the  eastern  margin  of  the  Gibson  Desert  and  is  characterised  by  isolated 
 plateaux and sand ridges separated by ephemeral creeks, rising to more elevated terrain along 
 the east-west axis of the Musgrave Block.  Local elevations rise from approximately 500 metres 
 above  sea  level  on  the  plain  to  650  metres  on  the  hilltops.    The  vegetation  is  dominated  by 
 broad expanses of Spinifex and annual grassland, interspersed with isolated shrubs and trees, 
 consistent with a continental desert climatic regime. 
 TENURE AND EXPLORATION ACCESS

 Project,  which  includes  three  other  exploration  licences  (E69/1662,  E69/1663,  E69/1700).

 Figure 2: Musgrave Block Regional Geology 
  Discovery Nickel Limited – Musgrave Project   5

15.text: The Musgrave Block formed during a series of continental collision events when the North, West

16.text: and South Australian Cratons collided during the Mesoproterozoic.  The history and correlation

17.text: of  these  collision  events  is  known  almost  entirely  from  the  geological  provinces  that  were

18.text: deformed during the collisions, and which are exposed around the peripheries of the cratons.

19.text: These provinces are only modestly researched and regional correlations are made difficult by

text:
The Musgrave Block formed during a series of continental collision events when the North, West 
 and South Australian Cratons collided during the Mesoproterozoic.  The history and correlation 
 of  these  collision  events  is  known  almost  entirely  from  the  geological  provinces  that  were 
 deformed during the collisions, and which are exposed around the peripheries of the cratons.  
 These provinces are only modestly researched and regional correlations are made difficult by

8.text: Discovery Nickel are targeting the igneous rocks of the Giles Complex, which intruded late in

9.text: the granulite facies deformation event, and may be as young as 1078Ma.  The Giles Complex is

10.text: mapped as more than 20 separate intrusions distributed over 500km in an east-west direction.

11.text: Three  principal  source  magma  types  are  recognised  in  the  Giles  Complex  intrusions;  a  high-

12.text: magnesium  basaltic  melt,  a  gabbroic  melt  and  a  more  evolved,  troctolitic  melt  that  shows

13.text: chemical  evidence  of  contamination  by  crustal  rocks.    The  Complex  can  be  subdivided  into

14.text: domains  based  on  the  limited  geochemical  criteria.    In  general,  intrusions  in  the  west  and

15.text: southwest  of  the  Musgrave  Block  represent  chemically  more  evolved  compositions,  olivine

16.text: gabbro and troctolite containing vanadiferous magnetite horizons, than those in east.  The depth

17.text: of  intrusion  is  interpreted  to  decrease  to  the  southwest,  exposing  magmas  intruded  at  high

18.text: structural levels and intruded into brittle crust.  The magma compositions and geological setting

19.text: are comparable with intrusions that host world class min

20.text: eralisation in other terrains, such as the

22.text: ain Plutonic Suite that hosts the Voisey’s Bay deposit, and represent attractive targets for the

23.text: discovery of magmatic nickel-copper sulphide deposits.

25.text: Following the Giles Complex magmatic event, the Musgrave Block underwent significant erosion

26.text: coeval with the development of extensive sedimentary basins across much of Central Australia.

text:
Discovery Nickel are targeting the igneous rocks of the Giles Complex, which intruded late in 
 the granulite facies deformation event, and may be as young as 1078Ma.  The Giles Complex is 
 mapped as more than 20 separate intrusions distributed over 500km in an east-west direction.  
 Three  principal  source  magma  types  are  recognised  in  the  Giles  Complex  intrusions;  a  high-
 magnesium  basaltic  melt,  a  gabbroic  melt  and  a  more  evolved,  troctolitic  melt  that  shows 
 chemical  evidence  of  contamination  by  crustal  rocks.    The  Complex  can  be  subdivided  into 
 domains  based  on  the  limited  geochemical  criteria.    In  general,  intrusions  in  the  west  and 
 southwest  of  the  Musgrave  Block  represent  chemically  more  evolved  compositions,  olivine 
 gabbro and troctolite containing vanadiferous magnetite horizons, than those in east.  The depth 
 of  intrusion  is  interpreted  to  decrease  to  the  southwest,  exposing  magmas  intruded  at  high 
 structural levels and intruded into brittle crust.  The magma compositions and geological setting 
 are comparable with intrusions that host world class min
 eralisation in other terrains, such as the 
 ain Plutonic Suite that hosts the Voisey’s Bay deposit, and represent attractive targets for the 
 discovery of magmatic nickel-copper sulphide deposits. 
 Following the Giles Complex magmatic event, the Musgrave Block underwent significant erosion 
 coeval with the development of extensive sedimentary basins across much of Central Australia.  
 o  affect  the  Musgrave  Block  was  the  Peterman  Ranges 
 The  last  significant  geological  event  t
 Orogeny,  at  about  550Ma,  when  north-directed  thrust  faulting  uplifted  the  block  and  imparted 
 the evident east-west structural grain. 
 PREVIOUS WORK 
 Previous Work by Other Companies 
 Regional studies by the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) during 1966-1968 led 
 to  the  first  detailed  mapping  and  chemical  analysis  of  the  Bentley  Supergroup  and  Giles 
 Complex  rocks.    The  Australian  Geological  Survey  Organisation  (now  Geoscience  Australia) 
 initiated a special study of the Giles Complex in 1987.  This study was concentrated around the 
 most  significant  exposures  straddling  the  Western  Australia-South  Australia  border  and 
 provided  new mapping, age data, and analytical information designed to determine the origin 
 and evolution of the Giles Complex rocks.  During 2002, the GSWA completed a 400m-spac
 ed 
 airborne magnetic and radiometric survey over the Western Australia portion of the Musgrave 
 region, providing additional detailed data with which the regional geology can be reconciled. 
 In general the Musgrave region has received limited exploration attention, in part because of its 
 location  within  lands  requiring  consent  for  access  from  the  indigenous  lan
 dholders.    Mineral 
 xploration  data  submitted  to  the  Mines  Department  of  Western  Australia  is  scant,  typically 
 incorporating initial data reviews, with access to ground often not achieved.   
 In 1988, BHP Minerals conducted rock chip and s
 tream sediment sampling in the area targeting 
 opper-nickel mineralisation in the Giles Complex rocks. The results did not show significantly 
 anomalous results and the ground was dropped. 
 In  2002,  Falconbridge  (Australia)  Pty  Ltd  completed  a  regional  review  of  the  Giles  Complex 
 rocks based on published geology and geophysical data. Falconbridge then commissioned an 
 airborne magnetic and EM (GeoTEM) survey that completely covered E69/1640, E69/1641 and 
 E69/1642  in  early  2003.  Modelling  of  the  EM  data  by  Falconbridge  shows  that  the  recent 
 overburden is highly conductive, suggesting caution in the interpretation of EM data. However,

text:
Following the recognition of the features considered to be important in controlling the formation 
 of  Ni-Cu  mineralisation  within  the  world’s  great  nickel  provinces  an  interpretation  of  the 
 Musgrave aeromagnetic data, recently flown by the GSWA, was undertaken.  This interpretation 
 highlighted  several  aeromagnetic  and  gravity  anomalies  within  DNL  Musgrave  tenements 
 thought to be due to mafic and ultramafic rocks with the potential to host Ni-Cu mineralisation. 
 Discovery Nickel attended a land access meeting in August 2005 to finalise the musgraves land 
 access agreement. In attendance were the Ngaanyatjarra Council, representing the Native Title 
 Claimants, and a number of tradional Owners.  
 EXPLORATION WORK PLANNED TO BE COMPLETED BY DISCOVERY NICKEL LIMITED    
 DURING THE NEXT 12 MONTHS  
 During the next twelve months Discovery Nickel Limited plans to complete the following work on 
 tenements E69/1640, E69/1641 and E69/1642: 
 •  Site clearance of work areas by Traditional Owners and Native Title Claimants. July 06  
 •  Ongoing Interpretation of the airborne EM surveys to identify strong anomalies/basement 
 conductors potentially due to Ni-Cu mineralisation, associated with the interpreted Giles 
 Complex intrusions. 
 •  Follow up  anomlies/basement conductors from the airborne EM (GEOTEM) with ground 
 EM in order to clarify targets. 
 •  Drill test any warranted targets. 
 Expenditure for E69/1640, E69/1641 and E69/1642 for the year ended 22 January 2006 was 
 $20269,  $15320  and  $16421  respectively.    A detailed  expenditure  statement  is  included  in 
 Since  acquiring  E69/1640,  E69/1641  and  E69/1642  the  focus  of  Discovery  Nickel’s  work  has 
 been to identify electromagnetic, aeromagnetic and gravity anomalies, thought to sourced from 
 Giles Complex intrusions, with the potential to host Voisey’s Bay style NI-Cu mineralisation.   
 In this period Discovery Nickel was finally able to finalise a Land Access Agreement with the 
 Ngaanyatjarra Land Council.  
 It  is  now  Discovery  Nickel’s  intention  to  follow  up  conductive  anomalies  from  the  Geotem 
 survey with ground EM surveys and to drill test any targets generated if warranted.
